blurb: The Bhikkhunī-pakiṇṇaka (“the assorted rules for nuns”) is a collection of miscellaneous rules and regulations for nuns outside the Pātimokkha. This collection only exists in the Mahāsaṁghika school and its sub-schools.

translated_name: Monastic Law of the Dharmaguptaka School
blurb: The Monastic Law for the Dharmaguptaka school in Gandhari. This school originally flourished in North-western India and had a large influence on Central Asia and China. Monastics in East Asia follow this Vinaya.
children: [{'uid': 'pgd-dg-bu-pm', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Pātimokkha', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules ', 'acronym': 'Pgd Dg Bu Pm', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 250 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pgd', 'root_lang_name': 'Gāndhārī', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}]

blurb: The Khandhakas (“the Chapters”) comprise the rules and regulations of both Sanghas that fall outside of the monastic code, the pātimokkha. There are about 20 individual Khandhakas, most of which discuss a more or less unified topic. The Khandhakas include a variety of material, such as assorted biographical material of a number of eminent disciples and some notorious ones. They also incorporate a few Jātakas and other tales, as well as the stories of the first communal recitation after the Buddha’s passing away and the famous Vesālī affair, sometimes known as “the second council.” The whole collection is structured around the life of the Buddha after his awakening.

blurb: The Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for nuns,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 366 such rules for the nuns, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the nuns’ rules”) contains the monastic code for nuns, the Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga is divided into five chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pārājika. The exact meaning of the Pali word is disputed, but there is no doubt that it refers to expulsion from the Sangha. There are four such rules for the monks, all of which are shared with the nuns. Anyone who breaches any of these rules immediately loses his status as a monk. He is expelled from the Sangha and ineligible for re-ordination for the rest of his life. The pārājikas, together with the next category of rules, the saṅghādisesas, are collectively known as serious offenses, garukāpatti. These rules are the most fundamental ones for the proper living of the monastic life.
children: [{'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1', 'root_name': 'Methunadhamma', 'translated_name': 'Sexual Intercourse ', 'acronym': 'Bu Pj 1', 'blurb': 'A monk who has sexual intercourse is expelled. The introduction to the rule tells the background story to the laying down of the monastic law. The main principle applied by the Buddha was to lay down rules and procedures only when required by circumstances.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2', 'root_name': 'Adinnādāna', 'translated_name': 'Theft ', 'acronym': 'Bu Pj 2', 'blurb': 'A monk who steals anything of value is expelled.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3', 'root_name': 'Manussaviggaha', 'translated_name': 'Murder ', 'acronym': 'Bu Pj 3', 'blurb': 'A monk who kills a human being is expelled. The origin narrative to this rule includes an unusual and much debated story about a number of monks who meditate on the unattractiveness of the body. As a result they end up committing suicide and asking others to kill them. The Buddha then teaches the meditation on mindfulness of breathing.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb-pj4', 'root_name': 'Uttarimanussadhamma', 'translated_name': 'Laying False Claim to Superhuman Attainments ', 'acronym': 'Bu Pj 4', 'blurb': 'A monk who falsely claims a profound spiritual attainment is expelled. In the origin story to this rule the Buddha declares that anyone who gets people to support him or her by lying about their spiritual attainments is the worst kind of thief.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}]

translated_name: Monastic Law of the Mūlasarvāstivāda School
blurb: The Monastic Law for the Mūlasarvāstivāda school in Tibetan. The debate about the origins of this school is still ongoing but it is clear that it had a large influence on Central Asia. Monastics of the Tibetan tradition follow this Vinaya. Besides the Tibetan text, we also have a full Vinaya translation in Chinese, and a part of the original Sanskrit.
children: [{'uid': 'xct-mu-kd', 'root_name': 'Khandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Chapters on Legal Topics ', 'acronym': 'Xct Mu Kd', 'blurb': 'The Khandhakas (“the Chapters”) comprise the rules and regulations of both Sanghas that fall outside of the monastic code, the pātimokkha. There are about 20 individual Khandhakas, most of which discuss a more or less unified topic. The Khandhakas include a variety of material, such as assorted biographical material of a number of eminent disciples and some notorious ones. They also incorporate a few Jātakas and other tales. The whole collection is structured around the life of the Buddha after his awakening.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'xct', 'root_lang_name': 'Tibetan', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'xct-mu-bu-pm', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Pātimokkha', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules ', 'acronym': 'Xct Mu Bu Pm', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 258 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'xct', 'root_lang_name': 'Tibetan', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'xct-mu-bu-vb', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Vibhaṅga', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules and Their Analysis ', 'acronym': 'Xct Mu Bu Vb', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the monks’ rules”) contains the monastic code for monks, the Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Vibhaṅga is divided into eight chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'xct', 'root_lang_name': 'Tibetan', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'xct-mu-bi-pm', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhunī Pātimokkha', 'translated_name': 'Nuns’ Rules ', 'acronym': 'Xct Mu Bi Pm', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for nuns,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 366 such rules for the nuns, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'xct', 'root_lang_name': 'Tibetan', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'xct-mu-bi-vb', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhunī Vibhaṅga', 'translated_name': 'Nuns’ Rules and Their Analysis ', 'acronym': 'Xct Mu Bi', 'blurb': 'The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the nuns’ rules”) contains the monastic code for nuns, the Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga is divided into six chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'xct', 'root_lang_name': 'Tibetan', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'xct-mu-khv', 'root_name': 'Khuddakavatthu', 'translated_name': 'Minor Matters ', 'acronym': 'Xct Mu Khv', 'blurb': 'The Khuddakavatthu (“the minor matters”) is a minor Vinaya work preserved in Chinese and Tibetan translations.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'xct', 'root_lang_name': 'Tibetan', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'xct-mu-utg', 'root_name': 'Uttaragantha (1st)', 'translated_name': 'Appendix (1st) ', 'acronym': 'Utg', 'blurb': 'The first Uttaragantha (“the first appendix”) contains appendices, such as the Upāliparipucchā (“the questions of Upāli”) which is a parallel of a chapter in the Theravāda Parivāra.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'xct', 'root_lang_name': 'Tibetan', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'xct-mu-utg-2', 'root_name': 'Uttaragantha (2nd)', 'translated_name': 'Appendix (2nd) ', 'acronym': 'Utg 2', 'blurb': 'The second Uttaragantha (“the second appendix”) is an extended version of the first Uttaragantha.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'xct', 'root_lang_name': 'Tibetan', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'xct-mu-bu-kam', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Kammavācā', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Legal Proceedings ', 'acronym': 'Xct Mu Bu Kam', 'blurb': 'The Bhikkhu-kammavācā (“the monks’ legal proceedings”) are compilations of the formulas that are recited by monks to carry out the legal proceedings of the Sangha. They were excerpted from the Vibhaṅga.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'xct', 'root_lang_name': 'Tibetan', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}]

blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 250 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The Parivāra, “the Compendium”, is a technical analysis of the content of the Suttavibhaṅga and the Khandhakas. It summarizes and distils the essence of the Vinaya, leaving out all narratives and stories. The Parivāra is unique to the Theravada school and it is probable that it was compiled in the sectarian period. Its manner of analysis shares certain characteristics with the Abhidhamma, such as expanding and filling in schemes of classification not given in full detail in the other canonical texts.

blurb: The Bhikkhunī-pakiṇṇaka (“the assorted rules for nuns”) is a collection of miscellaneous rules and regulations for nuns outside the Pātimokkha. This collection only exists in the Mahāsaṁghika school and its sub-schools.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 250 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the monks’ rules”) contains the monastic code for monks, the Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Vibhaṅga is divided into eight chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.

blurb: There are seven adhikaraṇasamathadhamma, “principles for the settling of legal issues”, which are the same for the nuns and the monks. These are not rules in the ordinary sense and as such fall outside of the classification into serious and light offenses. Instead, they set out the proper methods for dealing with legal issues. The detailed explanation for these is found in the Samathakkhandhaka. The legal issues to be settled through these principles fall into four categories: disputes, accusations, offenses, and proceedings. “Proceedings” includes monastic procedures such as ordination and the keeping of the observance day (uposatha).

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pārājika. The exact meaning of the Pali word is disputed, but there is no doubt that it refers to expulsion from the monastic Sangha. There are eight such rules for the nuns, four of which are shared with the monks. Anyone who breaches any of these rules immediately loses her status as a nun. She is expelled from the Sangha and ineligible for re-ordination for the rest of her life. The pārājikas, together with the next category of rules, the saṅghādisesas, are collectively known as serious offenses, garukāpatti. These rules are the most fundamental ones for the proper living of the monastic life.

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as sekhiya, “involving training”. There are seventy-five such rules, and they are the same both for the monks and the nuns. The sekhiyas are mostly rules of etiquette. Breaking a sekhiya is only considered to be a transgression if the offender is acting out of disrespect for the rule.

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as sekhiya, “involving training”. There are seventy-five such rules, and they are the same both for the monks and the nuns. The sekhiyas are mostly rules of etiquette. Breaking a sekhiya is only considered to be a transgression if the offender is acting out of disrespect for the rule.

blurb: The Khandhakas (“the Chapters”) comprise the rules and regulations of both Sanghas that fall outside of the monastic code, the pātimokkha. There are about 20 individual Khandhakas, most of which discuss a more or less unified topic. The Khandhakas include a variety of material, such as assorted biographical material of a number of eminent disciples and some notorious ones. They also incorporate a few Jātakas and other tales. The whole collection is structured around the life of the Buddha after his awakening.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are about 250 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The Khandhakas (“the Chapters”) comprise the rules and regulations of both Sanghas that fall outside of the monastic code, the pātimokkha. There are about 20 individual Khandhakas, most of which discuss a more or less unified topic. The Khandhakas include a variety of material, such as assorted biographical material of a number of eminent disciples and some notorious ones. They also incorporate a few Jātakas and other tales, as well as the stories of the first communal recitation after the Buddha’s passing away and the famous Vesālī affair, sometimes known as “the second council.” The whole collection is structured around the life of the Buddha after his awakening.

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as nissaggiya pācittiya, “entailing relinquishment and confession”. There are thirty such rules for the nuns, the same number as for the monks, although only eighteen are held in common. These rules, together with the remaining rules of the Monastic Code, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is usually no penalty apart from confession. For the nissaggiya pācittiyas, however, any item involved in the committing of an offense must be relinquished. Once the offense has been confessed, the item is, with a few exceptions, returned to the offender.

translated_name: Monastic Law of the Sarvāstivāda School
blurb: The Monastic Law for the Sarvāstivāda school in Chinese. This school spread throughout North India and Central Asia. The Sarvāstivāda Vinaya was the most common Vinaya in China before they changed to the Dharmaguptaka. The Sarvāstivāda school is now extinct. Most of the Vinaya texts we have today were translated from about 404–409 CE by the Kashmiri monks Kumārajīva and Puṇyatāra. When Puṇyatāra died, Dharmaruci replaced him and finished the translation.
children: [{'uid': 'lzh-sarv-bu-vb', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Vibhaṅga', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules and Their Analysis ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Sarv Bu Vb', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the monks’ rules”) contains the monastic code for monks, the Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Vibhaṅga is divided into eight chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-sarv-kd', 'root_name': 'Khandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Chapters on Legal Topics ', 'acronym': 'Sarv Kd', 'blurb': 'The Khandhakas (“the Chapters”) comprise the rules and regulations of both Sanghas that fall outside of the monastic code, the pātimokkha. There are about 20 individual Khandhakas, most of which discuss a more or less unified topic. The Khandhakas include a variety of material, such as assorted biographical material of a number of eminent disciples and some notorious ones. They also incorporate a few Jātakas and other tales, as well as the stories of the first communal recitation after the Buddha’s passing away and the famous Vesālī affair, sometimes known as “the second council.” The whole collection is structured around the life of the Buddha after his awakening.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-sarv-bi-vb', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhunī Vibhaṅga', 'translated_name': 'Nuns’ Rules and Their Analysis ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Sarv Bi Vb', 'blurb': 'The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the nuns’ rules”) contains the monastic code for nuns, the Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga is divided into five chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-sarv-ve', 'root_name': 'Ekottara', 'translated_name': 'Numbered Passages ', 'acronym': 'Sarv VE', 'blurb': 'The Ekottara (“the numbered passages”) is a text found in the Sarvāstivāda and Dharmaguptaka schools. It is a parallel of a chapter in the Theravāda Parivāra.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-sarv-upp', 'root_name': 'Upāliparipucchā', 'translated_name': 'Questions of Upāli ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Sarv Upp', 'blurb': 'The Upāliparipucchā (“the questions of Upāli”) is found in the Sarvāstivāda school and as two independent texts not affiliated with a school. In other schools, the Upāliparipucchā is included in other works, such as the Mūlasarvāstivāda Uttaragantha and the Theravāda Parivāra.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-sarv-ba', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Ajjhāya', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Recitation ', 'acronym': 'BA', 'blurb': 'The Bhikkhu-ajjhāya (“the monks’ recitation”) is a text only found in the Sarvāstivāda school.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-sarv-bu-pm', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Pātimokkha (1st)', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules (1st) ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Sarv Bu Pm', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pācittiya, “entailing confession”. There are ninety-two such rules for the monks, seventy of which are shared with the nuns. This is the largest class of rules in the Monastic Code. These rules, together with all the other rules apart from those entailing expulsion and suspension, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is no penalty apart from confession.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-pakiṇṇaka (“the assorted rules for monks”) is a collection of miscellaneous rules and regulations for monks outside the Pātimokkha. Many of the rules also apply to nuns. This collection only exists in the Mahāsaṁghika school and its sub-schools.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 250 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 251 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the monks’ rules”) contains the monastic code for monks, the Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Vibhaṅga is divided into eight chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pācittiya, “entailing confession”. There are one hundred and sixty-six such rules for the nuns, seventy of which are shared with the monks. This is the largest class of rules in the Monastic Code. These rules, together with all the other rules apart from those entailing expulsion and suspension, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is no penalty apart from confession.

blurb: The Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for nuns,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 348 such rules for the nuns, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as nissaggiya pācittiya, “entailing relinquishment and confession”. There are thirty such rules for the monks, the same number as for the nuns, although only eighteen are held in common. These rules, together with the remaining rules of the Monastic Code, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is usually no penalty apart from confession. For the nissaggiya pācittiyas, however, any item involved in the committing of an offense must be relinquished. Once the offense has been confessed, the item is, with a few exceptions, returned to the offender.

translated_name: Monastic Law of the Lokuttaravāda School
blurb: The Monastic Law for the Lokuttaravāda school in Sanskrit. This is a sub-school of the Mahāsaṁghika and is now extinct. It is not known where the adherents of this school lived, but in the early 7th century, a community existed in Bāmīyan. The text is incomplete, and most of what we have today was discovered in Tibet as palm-leaf manuscripts by Tripiṭakācārya Śri Rāhula Sānkṛtyāyana between 1935–1938. It is of special importance for bhikkhunī Vinaya studies, since it has the only complete Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga in an Indian language besides the Pāli.
children: [{'uid': 'san-lo-bi-nidana', 'root_name': 'Nidāna', 'translated_name': 'Origins ', 'acronym': 'Nidana', 'blurb': "The Nidāna (“introduction”) contains the story of the foundation of the nuns’ order and the eight garudhamma (“important rules”).", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'san', 'root_lang_name': 'Sanskrit', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'san-lo-bi-vb', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhunī Vibhaṅga', 'translated_name': 'Nuns’ Rules and Their Analysis ', 'acronym': 'San Lo Bi Vb', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the nuns’ rules”) contains the monastic code for nuns, the Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga is divided into eight chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”) and the dhamma-anudhamma (“the rules and their applications”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'san', 'root_lang_name': 'Sanskrit', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'san-lo-bi-pn', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhunī Pakiṇṇaka', 'translated_name': 'Assorted Rules for Nuns ', 'acronym': 'San Lo Bi Pn', 'blurb': 'The Bhikkhunī-pakiṇṇaka (“the assorted rules for nuns”) is a collection of miscellaneous rules and regulations for nuns outside the Pātimokkha. This collection only exists in the Mahāsaṁghika school and its sub-schools.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'san', 'root_lang_name': 'Sanskrit', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'san-lo-bu-pn', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Pakiṇṇaka', 'translated_name': 'Assorted Rules for Monks ', 'acronym': 'San Lo Bu Pn', 'blurb': 'The Bhikkhu-pakiṇṇaka (“the assorted rules for monks”) is a collection of miscellaneous rules and regulations for monks outside the Pātimokkha. Many of the rules also apply to nuns. This collection only exists in the Mahāsaṁghika school and its sub-schools.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'san', 'root_lang_name': 'Sanskrit', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'san-lo-bu-pm', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Pātimokkha', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules ', 'acronym': 'San Lo Bu Pm', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pāṭidesanīya, “entailing acknowledgement”. There are four such rules for the monks, none of which are shared with the nuns. What distinguishes these rules from the pācittiyas is the manner of confession. For these rules the confession is done using a unique formula, with the second rule being the only one in the Monastic Code where all the offenders confess together as a group.

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pārājika. The exact meaning of the Pali word is disputed, but there is no doubt that it refers to expulsion from the monastic Sangha. There are eight such rules for the nuns, four of which are shared with the monks. Anyone who breaches any of these rules immediately loses her status as a nun. She is expelled from the Sangha and ineligible for re-ordination for the rest of her life. The pārājikas, together with the next category of rules, the saṅghādisesas, are collectively known as serious offenses, garukāpatti. These rules are the most fundamental ones for the proper living of the monastic life.

blurb: There are seven adhikaraṇasamathadhamma, “principles for the settling of legal issues”, which are the same for the nuns and the monks. These are not rules in the ordinary sense and as such fall outside of the classification into serious and light offenses. Instead, they set out the proper methods for dealing with legal issues. The detailed explanation for these is found in the Samathakkhandhaka. The legal issues to be settled through these principles fall into four categories: disputes, accusations, offenses, and proceedings. “Proceedings” includes monastic procedures such as ordination and the keeping of the observance day (uposatha).

blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 258 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

translated_name: Monks’ Rules of the Kāśyapīya School
blurb: This Bhikkhu-pātimokkha belongs to the Kāśyapīya school. This school was founded by the monks sent to the Himalayan region as missionaries by Aśoka. The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 246 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: These are some individual texts that do not belong to any of the schools above. They are either from schools whose Vinaya texts have been mostly lost, or are works that have not yet been attributed to a school.
children: [{'uid': 'lzh-ka-bu-pm', 'root_name': 'Kāśyapīya Bhikkhu Pātimokkha', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules of the Kāśyapīya School ', 'acronym': 'Ka Bu Pm', 'blurb': "This Bhikkhu-pātimokkha belongs to the Kāśyapīya school. This school was founded by the monks sent to the Himalayan region as missionaries by Aśoka. The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 246 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-upp-bu', 'root_name': 'Upāliparipṛcchā (T1466)', 'translated_name': 'Questions of Upāli ', 'acronym': 'Upp', 'blurb': 'The Upāliparipucchā (“the questions of Upāli”) is found in the Sarvāstivāda school and as two independent texts not affiliated with a school. In other schools, an Upāliparipucchā is included in other works, such as the Mūlasarvāstivāsa Uttaragantha and the Theravāda Parivāra. This version, 優波離問佛經 at Taishō Vol. 24, No. 1466, was translated by Guṇaśāla in the Song Dynasty in one scroll. blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as aniyata, “undetermined”. There are two such rules for the monks, but none for the nuns. These are procedures to establish a course of action when a monk is accused of behaving in a sexually inappropriate way with a woman.
children: [{'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1', 'root_name': 'Paṭhamaaniyata', 'translated_name': 'First Undetermined Offence ', 'acronym': 'Bu Ay 1', 'blurb': 'A female lay disciple may see a monk sitting in a secluded place with a woman. If she accuses him of an offense entailing expulsion, suspension, or confession, and he admits to the offense, then he incurs an offense accordingly.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb-ay2', 'root_name': 'Dutiyaaniyata', 'translated_name': 'Second Undetermined Offence ', 'acronym': 'Bu Ay 2', 'blurb': 'A female lay disciple may see a monk sitting in private with a woman. If she accuses him of an offense entailing suspension or confession, and he admits to the offense, then he incurs an offense accordingly.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}]

blurb: The Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, “the Monastic Code for nuns”, contains the core rules of the monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 311 such rules for the nuns, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the last group, the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. At present the Pātimokkha is only found embedded in the Suttavibhaṅga (“the Analysis of the Pātimokkha rules”), in which each rule is surrounded by explanatory material. Originally, however, the Pātimokkha probably existed as an independent text, known as the Pātimokkha-sutta. This can be seen from the fact that rules sometimes refer to other rules that immediately precede them, a connection that is now severed since the Suttavibhaṅga material separates the rules from each other.
children: [{'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-pm-pj', 'root_name': 'Pārājika', 'translated_name': 'Expulsion ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as pārājika. The exact meaning of the Pali word is disputed, but there is no doubt that it refers to expulsion from the monastic Sangha. There are eight such rules for the nuns, four of which are shared with the monks. Anyone who breaches any of these rules immediately loses her status as a nun. She is expelled from the Sangha and ineligible for re-ordination for the rest of her life. The pārājikas, together with the next category of rules, the saṅghādisesas, are collectively known as serious offenses, garukāpatti. These rules are the most fundamental ones for the proper living of the monastic life.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-pm-ss', 'root_name': 'Saṅghādisesa', 'translated_name': 'Suspension ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as saṅghādisesa. The meaning of the word is disputed, but according to the commentary it means that the Sangha is required at the beginning (ādi) and for the rest (sesa) of the procedure. There are seventeen such rules for the nuns, seven of which are shared with the monks. Offenders must undergo a period of probation before being rehabilitated to their former status in the Sangha.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-pm-np', 'root_name': 'Nissaggiya Pācittiya', 'translated_name': 'Relinquishment With Confession ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as nissaggiya pācittiya, “entailing relinquishment and confession”. There are thirty such rules for the nuns, the same number as for the monks, although only eighteen are held in common. These rules, together with the remaining rules of the Monastic Code, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is usually no penalty apart from confession. For the nissaggiya pācittiyas, however, any item involved in the committing of an offense must be relinquished. Once the offense has been confessed, the item is, with a few exceptions, returned to the offender.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-pm-pc', 'root_name': 'Pācittiya', 'translated_name': 'Confession ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as pācittiya, “entailing confession”. There are one hundred and sixty-six such rules for the nuns, seventy of which are shared with the monks. This is the largest class of rules in the Monastic Code. These rules, together with all the other rules apart from those entailing expulsion and suspension, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is no penalty apart from confession.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-pm-pd', 'root_name': 'Pāṭidesanīya', 'translated_name': 'Acknowledgment ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as pāṭidesanīya, “entailing acknowledgement”. There are eight such rules for the nuns. These eight rules for the nuns are equivalent to a single rule for the monks (bhikkhu-pācittiya 39). In summary, they say that a nun who asks for special food must acknowledge the offense.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-pm-sk', 'root_name': 'Sekhiya', 'translated_name': 'Rules for Training ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as sekhiya, “involving training”. There are seventy-five such rules, and they are the same both for the monks and the nuns. The sekhiyas are mostly rules of etiquette. Breaking a sekhiya is only considered to be a transgression if the offender is acting out of disrespect for the rule.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-pm-as', 'root_name': 'Adhikaraṇasamatha', 'translated_name': 'Settling Legal Issues ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "There are seven adhikaraṇasamathadhamma, “principles for the settling of legal issues”, which are the same for the nuns and the monks. These are not rules in the ordinary sense and as such fall outside of the classification into serious and light offenses. Instead, they set out the proper methods for dealing with legal issues. The detailed explanation for these is found in the Samathakkhandhaka. The legal issues to be settled through these principles fall into four categories: disputes, accusations, offenses, and proceedings. “Proceedings” includes monastic procedures such as ordination and the keeping of the observance day (uposatha).", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}]

blurb: The Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for nuns,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 357 such rules for the nuns, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for nuns,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 355 such rules for the nuns, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

translated_name: Monastic Law of the Mūlasarvāstivāda School
blurb: The Monastic Law for the Mūlasarvāstivāda school in Chinese. The debate about the origins of this school is still ongoing but it is clear that it had a large influence on Central Asia. Monastics of the Tibetan tradition follow this Vinaya. Most of the Vinaya texts in Chinese we have today were translated between 695 and 713 CE by Yijing. We also have a full Vinaya translation in Tibetan, and a part of the original Sanskrit.
children: [{'uid': 'lzh-mu-bu-vb', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Vibhaṅga', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules and Their Analysis ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mu Bu Vb', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the monks’ rules”) contains the monastic code for monks, the Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Vibhaṅga is divided into eight chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mu-bi-vb', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhunī Vibhaṅga', 'translated_name': 'Nuns’ Rules and Their Analysis ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mu Bi Vb', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the nuns’ rules”) contains the monastic code for nuns, the Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga is divided into seven chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mu-kd', 'root_name': 'Khandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Chapters on Legal Topics ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mu Kd', 'blurb': 'The Khandhakas (“the Chapters”) comprise the rules and regulations of both Sanghas that fall outside of the monastic code, the pātimokkha. There are about 20 individual Khandhakas, most of which discuss a more or less unified topic. The Khandhakas include a variety of material, such as assorted biographical material of a number of eminent disciples and some notorious ones. They also incorporate a few Jātakas and other tales, as well as the stories of the first communal recitation after the Buddha’s passing away and the famous Vesālī affair, sometimes known as “the second council.” The whole collection is structured around the life of the Buddha after his awakening.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mu-khv', 'root_name': 'Khuddakavatthu', 'translated_name': 'Minor Matters ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mu Khv', 'blurb': 'The Khuddakavatthu (“the minor matters”) is a minor Vinaya work preserved in Chinese and Tibetan translations.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mu-bu-pm', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Pātimokkha', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mu Bu Pm', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 248 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mu-bi-pm', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhunī Pātimokkha', 'translated_name': 'Nuns’ Rules ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mu Bi Pm', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for nuns,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 357 such rules for the nuns, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mu-bu-kam', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Kammavācā', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Legal Proceedings ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mu Bu Kam', 'blurb': 'The Bhikkhu-kammavācā (“the monks’ legal proceedings”) are compilations of the formulas that are recited by monks to carry out the legal proceedings of the Sangha. They were excerpted from the Vibhaṅga.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'ot', 'root_name': 'Other', 'translated_name': 'Other Texts of the Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya ', 'acronym': 'Other Mu Vi', 'blurb': 'The other texts of the Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya are some appendices to the Vinaya of this school. In the Taishō Tripiṭaka, they are found from T1442-T1451.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}]

blurb: The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the nuns’ rules”) contains the monastic code for nuns, the Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga is divided into eight chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”) and the dhamma-anudhamma (“the rules and their applications”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 263 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the nuns’ rules”) contains the monastic code for nuns, the Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga is divided into six chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pācittiya, “entailing confession”. There are ninety-two such rules for the monks, seventy of which are shared with the nuns. This is the largest class of rules in the Monastic Code. These rules, together with all the other rules apart from those entailing expulsion and suspension, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is no penalty apart from confession.

blurb: The Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for nuns,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 373 such rules for the nuns, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule.

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as saṅghādisesa. The meaning of the word is disputed, but according to the commentary it means that the Sangha is required at the beginning (ādi) and for the rest (sesa) of the procedure. There are seventeen such rules for the nuns, seven of which are shared with the monks. Offenders must undergo a period of probation before being rehabilitated to their former status in the Sangha.

blurb: The Khandhakas (“the Chapters”) comprise the rules and regulations of both Sanghas that fall outside of the monastic code, the pātimokkha. There are about 20 individual Khandhakas, most of which discuss a more or less unified topic. The Khandhakas include a variety of material, such as assorted biographical material of a number of eminent disciples and some notorious ones. They also incorporate a few Jātakas and other tales, as well as the stories of the first communal recitation after the Buddha’s passing away and the famous Vesālī affair, sometimes known as “the second council.” The whole collection is structured around the life of the Buddha after his awakening.

translated_name: Monastic Law of the Mahāsaṅghika School
blurb: The Monastic Law for the Mahāsaṁghika school in Sanskrit. This school originally flourished in the area of Magadha in India and is now extinct. It was created during the first schism, and therefore its Vinaya has some unique features not found in other schools. Only the Bhikkhu-pātimokkha has been preserved in Sanskrit.
children: [{'uid': 'san-mg-bu-pm', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Pātimokkha', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules ', 'acronym': 'San Mg Bu Pm', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 218 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”) and the dhamma-anudhamma (“the rules and their applications”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'san', 'root_lang_name': 'Sanskrit', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}]

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as nissaggiya pācittiya, “entailing relinquishment and confession”. There are thirty such rules for the monks, the same number as for the nuns, although only eighteen are held in common. These rules, together with the remaining rules of the Monastic Code, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is usually no penalty apart from confession. For the nissaggiya pācittiyas, however, any item involved in the committing of an offense must be relinquished. Once the offense has been confessed, the item is, with a few exceptions, returned to the offender.

If he does not, he must relinquish the robe-cloth and confess the offense.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-np8', 'root_name': 'Upakkhata', 'translated_name': 'Requesting Fine Robes From a Robe Fund ', 'acronym': 'Bu Np 8', 'blurb': 'If a lay person wants to buy a robe for a monk, and the monk asks them for a fine robe, he must relinquish the robe and confess the offense.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-np9', 'root_name': 'Dutiyaupakkhata', 'translated_name': 'Requesting Fine Robes From a Combined Robe Fund ', 'acronym': 'Bu Np 9', 'blurb': 'If two separate lay people want to buy a robe for a monk, and the monk asks them to put their money together to buy him a fine robe, he must relinquish the robe and confess the offense.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-np10', 'root_name': 'Rāja', 'translated_name': 'Excessive Prompting for Robe Funds ', 'acronym': 'Bu Np 10', 'blurb': 'When money to be used for a monk’s robe has been placed with a steward in the proper way, that monk may hint to the steward that he needs a robe. If he does not get a robe in this way, but he does get one by acting inappropriately, he must relinquish the robe and confess the offense. This rule also prescribes the procedure through which a lay follower comes to hold money on behalf of a donor who wishes to support a monk.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-np11', 'root_name': 'Kosiya', 'translated_name': 'Silk Blanket ', 'acronym': 'Bu Np 11', 'blurb': 'A monk who makes a blanket containing silk must relinquish it and confess the offense.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-np12', 'root_name': 'Suddhakāla', 'translated_name': 'Pure Black Blanket ', 'acronym': 'Bu Np 12', 'blurb': 'A monk who makes a blanket entirely of black wool must relinquish it and confess the offense.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-np13', 'root_name': 'Dvebhāga', 'translated_name': 'A New Blanket Should Have Mixed Colors ', 'acronym': 'Bu Np 13', 'blurb': 'A monk who makes a blanket that contains more than fifty percent black wool must relinquish it and confess the offense.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-np14', 'root_name': 'Chabbassa', 'translated_name': 'A New Blanket Should be Kept for Six Years ', 'acronym': 'Bu Np 14', 'blurb': 'A monk who makes a blanket must wait for six years before making another. blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 248 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 218 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”) and the dhamma-anudhamma (“the rules and their applications”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pāṭidesanīya, “entailing acknowledgement”. There are eight such rules for the nuns. These eight rules for the nuns are equivalent to a single rule for the monks (bhikkhu-pācittiya 39). In summary, they say that a nun who asks for special food must acknowledge the offense.

blurb: The Khandhakas (“the Chapters”) comprise the rules and regulations of both Sanghas that fall outside of the monastic code, the pātimokkha. There are 22 individual Khandhakas, most of which discuss a more or less unified topic. The Khandhakas include a variety of material, such as assorted biographical material of a number of eminent disciples and some notorious ones. They also incorporate a few Jātakas and other tales, as well as the stories of the first communal recitation after the Buddha’s passing away and the famous Vesālī affair, sometimes known as “the second council.” The whole collection is structured around the life of the Buddha after his awakening.

translated_name: Monastic Law of the Theravāda School
blurb: The Monastic Law for the Theravāda school in Pali. This collection is followed by mendicants of the Theravāda school. It is the only Vinaya for which we have a complete collection in the original Indic.
children: [{'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Vibhaṅga', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules and Their Analysis ', 'acronym': 'Bu', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-vibhaṅga or Mahā-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the monks’ rules” or “the great analysis”), or simply the Vibhaṅga for short, contains the Monastic Code for monks, the Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Vibhaṅga is divided into eight chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”) and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter. These units begin with one or more origin stories, which tell the circumstances that led the Buddha to lay down a particular rule. The rule is then stated, followed by a word commentary that analyzes every significant word contained in the rule. After the word commentary follows a permutation series in which a variety of different scenarios are evaluated and offenses assigned as appropriate. At the end comes a non-offense clause, stating important exceptions to the rule, sometimes followed by individual case studies, in which the Buddha decides the offense incurred in ambiguous cases.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 405}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-vb', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhunī Vibhaṅga', 'translated_name': 'Nuns’ Rules and Their Analysis ', 'acronym': 'Bi', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the nuns’ rules”) contains the Monastic Code for nuns, the Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga is divided into seven chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter. These units begin with one or more origin stories, which tell the circumstances that led the Buddha to lay down a particular rule. The rule is then stated, followed by a word commentary that analyzes every significant word contained in the rule. After the word commentary follows a permutation series in which a variety of different scenarios are evaluated and offenses assigned as appropriate. At the end comes a non-offense clause, stating important exceptions to the rule, sometimes followed by individual case studies, in which the Buddha decides the offense incurred in ambiguous cases.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 335}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd', 'root_name': 'Khandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Chapters on Legal Topics ', 'acronym': 'Kd', 'blurb': 'The Khandhakas (“the Chapters”) comprise the rules and regulations of both Sanghas that fall outside of the Monastic Code, the Pātimokkha. There are 22 individual Khandhakas, most of which discuss a more or less unified topic. The Khandhakas include a variety of material, such as assorted biographical material of a number of eminent disciples and some notorious ones. They also incorporate a few Jātakas and other tales, as well as the stories of the first communal recitation after the Buddha’s passing away and the famous Vesālī affair, sometimes known as “the second council”. The whole collection is structured around the life of the Buddha after his awakening.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 66}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-pvr', 'root_name': 'Parivāra', 'translated_name': 'The Compendium ', 'acronym': 'Pvr', 'blurb': 'The Parivāra, “the Compendium”, is a technical analysis of the content of the Suttavibhaṅga and the Khandhakas. It summarizes and distils the essence of the Vinaya, leaving out all narratives and stories. The Parivāra is unique to the Theravada school and it is probable that it was compiled in the sectarian period. Its manner of analysis shares certain characteristics with the Abhidhamma, such as expanding and filling in schemes of classification not given in full detail in the other canonical texts.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 125}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Pātimokkha', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules ', 'acronym': 'Bu', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the Monastic Code for monks”, contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 227 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”) and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. At present the Pātimokkha is only found embedded in the Suttavibhaṅga (“the Analysis of the Pātimokkha rules”), in which each rule is surrounded by explanatory material. Originally, however, the Pātimokkha probably existed as an independent text, known as the Pātimokkha-sutta. This can be seen from the fact that rules sometimes refer to other rules that immediately precede them, a connection that is now severed since the Suttavibhaṅga material separates the rules from each other.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-pm', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhunī Pātimokkha', 'translated_name': 'Nuns’ Rules ', 'acronym': 'Bi', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, “the Monastic Code for nuns”, contains the core rules of the monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 311 such rules for the nuns, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the last group, the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. At present the Pātimokkha is only found embedded in the Suttavibhaṅga (“the Analysis of the Pātimokkha rules”), in which each rule is surrounded by explanatory material. Originally, however, the Pātimokkha probably existed as an independent text, known as the Pātimokkha-sutta. This can be seen from the fact that rules sometimes refer to other rules that immediately precede them, a connection that is now severed since the Suttavibhaṅga material separates the rules from each other.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}]

The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga is divided into seven chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the Monastic Code for monks”, contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 227 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”) and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. At present the Pātimokkha is only found embedded in the Suttavibhaṅga (“the Analysis of the Pātimokkha rules”), in which each rule is surrounded by explanatory material. Originally, however, the Pātimokkha probably existed as an independent text, known as the Pātimokkha-sutta. This can be seen from the fact that rules sometimes refer to other rules that immediately precede them, a connection that is now severed since the Suttavibhaṅga material separates the rules from each other.
children: [{'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-pj', 'root_name': 'Pārājika', 'translated_name': 'Expulsion ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as pārājika. The exact meaning of the Pali word is disputed, but there is no doubt that it refers to expulsion from the Sangha. There are four such rules for the monks, all of which are shared with the nuns. Anyone who breaches any of these rules immediately loses his status as a monk. He is expelled from the Sangha and ineligible for re-ordination for the rest of his life. The pārājikas, together with the next category of rules, the saṅghādisesas, are collectively known as serious offenses, garukāpatti. These rules are the most fundamental ones for the proper living of the monastic life.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-ss', 'root_name': 'Saṅghādisesa', 'translated_name': 'Suspension ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as saṅghādisesa. The meaning of the word is disputed, but according to the commentary it means that the Sangha is required at the beginning (ādi) and for the rest (sesa) of the procedure. There are thirteen such rules for the monks, seven of which are shared with the nuns. Offenders must undergo a period of probation before being rehabilitated to their former status in the Sangha.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-ay', 'root_name': 'Aniyata', 'translated_name': 'Undetermined ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as aniyata, “undetermined”. There are two such rules for the monks, but none for the nuns. These are procedures to establish a course of action when a monk is accused of behaving in a sexually inappropriate way with a woman.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-np', 'root_name': 'Nissaggiya Pācittiya', 'translated_name': 'Relinquishment With Confession ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as nissaggiya pācittiya, “entailing relinquishment and confession”. There are thirty such rules for the monks, the same number as for the nuns, although only eighteen are held in common. These rules, together with the remaining rules of the Monastic Code, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is usually no penalty apart from confession. For the nissaggiya pācittiyas, however, any item involved in the committing of an offense must be relinquished. Once the offense has been confessed, the item is, with a few exceptions, returned to the offender. These rules, together with all the other rules apart from those entailing expulsion and suspension, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. There are seventy-five such rules, and they are the same both for the monks and the nuns. The sekhiyas are mostly rules of etiquette. Breaking a sekhiya is only considered to be a transgression if the offender is acting out of disrespect for the rule.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-as', 'root_name': 'Adhikaraṇasamatha', 'translated_name': 'Settling Legal Issues ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "There are seven adhikaraṇasamathadhamma, “principles for the settling of legal issues”, which are the same for the nuns and the monks. These are not rules in the ordinary sense and as such fall outside of the classification into serious and light offenses. Instead, they set out the proper methods for dealing with legal issues. The detailed explanation for these is found in the Samathakkhandhaka. The legal issues to be settled through these principles fall into four categories: disputes, accusations, offenses, and proceedings. “Proceedings” includes monastic procedures such as ordination and the keeping of the observance day (uposatha).", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}]

translated_name: Monastic Law of the Mahāsaṅghika School
blurb: The Monastic Law for the Mahāsaṁghika school in Chinese. This school originally flourished in the area of Magadha in India and is now extinct. It was created during the first schism, and therefore its Vinaya has some unique features not found in other schools. Most of the Vinaya texts we have today were brought from Pāṭaliputra in India to China by the Chinese monk Faxian. He then translated them into Chinese together with the Indian monk Buddhabhadra from 416–418 CE.
children: [{'uid': 'lzh-mg-bu-vb', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Vibhaṅga', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules and Their Analysis ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mg Bu Vb', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the monks’ rules”) contains the monastic code for monks, the Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Vibhaṅga is divided into nine chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”) and the dhamma-anudhamma (“the rules and their applications”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mg-bu-pn', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Pakiṇṇaka', 'translated_name': 'Assorted Rules for Monks ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mg Bu Pn', 'blurb': 'The Bhikkhu-pakiṇṇaka (“the assorted rules for monks”) is a collection of miscellaneous rules and regulations for monks outside the Pātimokkha. Many of the rules also apply to nuns. This collection only exists in the Mahāsaṁghika school and its sub-schools.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mg-asc', 'root_name': 'Abhisamācārika', 'translated_name': 'Supplementary Regulations ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Asc', 'blurb': 'The Abhisamācārika (“the supplementary regulations”) is a text only found in the Mahāsaṅghika school and its sub-schools. The text has been transmitted in a Chinese translation and in a Sanskrit version that belongs to the Lokuttaravāda school.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mg-bi-vb', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhunī Vibhaṅga', 'translated_name': 'Nuns’ Rules and Their Analysis ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mg Bi Vb', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the nuns’ rules”) contains the monastic code for nuns, the Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga is divided into eight chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”) and the dhamma-anudhamma (“the rules and their applications”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mg-bi-pn', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhunī Pakiṇṇaka', 'translated_name': 'Assorted Rules for Nuns ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mg Bi Pn', 'blurb': 'The Bhikkhunī-pakiṇṇaka (“the assorted rules for nuns”) is a collection of miscellaneous rules and regulations for nuns outside the Pātimokkha. This collection only exists in the Mahāsaṁghika school and its sub-schools.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mg-bu-pm', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Pātimokkha', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mg Bu Pm', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 218 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”) and the dhamma-anudhamma (“the rules and their applications”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mg-bi-pm', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhunī Pātimokkha', 'translated_name': 'Nuns’ Rules ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mg Bi Pm', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for nuns,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 290 such rules for the nuns, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”) and the dhamma-anudhamma (“the rules and their applications”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mg-spp', 'root_name': 'Śāriputraparipṛcchā', 'translated_name': 'Questions of Sāriputta ', 'acronym': 'Spp', 'blurb': 'The Śāriputraparipṛcchā (“the questions of Sāriputta”) was translated into Chinese in the 4th or early 5th century.
