blurb: The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the nuns’ rules”) contains the monastic code for nuns, the Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga is divided into eight chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”) and the dhamma-anudhamma (“the rules and their applications”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.

blurb: The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the nuns’ rules”) contains the monastic code for nuns, the Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga is divided into six chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.

blurb: The Khandhakas (“the Chapters”) comprise the rules and regulations of both Sanghas that fall outside of the monastic code, the pātimokkha. There are about 20 individual Khandhakas, most of which discuss a more or less unified topic. The Khandhakas include a variety of material, such as assorted biographical material of a number of eminent disciples and some notorious ones. They also incorporate a few Jātakas and other tales. The whole collection is structured around the life of the Buddha after his awakening.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 258 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as sekhiya, “involving training”. There are seventy-five such rules, and they are the same both for the monks and the nuns. The sekhiyas are mostly rules of etiquette. Breaking a sekhiya is only considered to be a transgression if the offender is acting out of disrespect for the rule.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 218 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”) and the dhamma-anudhamma (“the rules and their applications”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for nuns,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 355 such rules for the nuns, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The Khandhakas (“the Chapters”) comprise the rules and regulations of both Sanghas that fall outside of the Monastic Code, the Pātimokkha. There are 22 individual Khandhakas, most of which discuss a more or less unified topic. The Khandhakas include a variety of material, such as assorted biographical material of a number of eminent disciples and some notorious ones. They also incorporate a few Jātakas and other tales, as well as the stories of the first communal recitation after the Buddha’s passing away and the famous Vesālī affair, sometimes known as “the second council”. The whole collection is structured around the life of the Buddha after his awakening.
children: [{'uid': 'pli-tv-kd1', 'root_name': 'Mahākhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Going Forth ', 'acronym': 'Kd 1', 'blurb': 'The Mahākhandhaka, “the Great chapter”, begins by telling the story of the Buddha after his awakening. Three of the Buddha’s first and most well-known discourses—the Setting in motion of the wheel of the Teaching, the Characteristics of non-self, and the Discourse on fire—are given in full. As he starts to accumulate disciples, an ordination procedure gradually evolves. A large number of rules that concern ordination, especially about the eligibility of the candidate, are laid down, as are rules governing the relationship between teacher and student, including rules about novices.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd2', 'root_name': 'Uposathakkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Sabbath ', 'acronym': 'Kd 2', 'blurb': "The Uposathakkhandhaka, “the Chapter on the observance day”, lays down the rules concerning the twice-monthly observance day, the uposatha, which is kept on the day of the full moon and the new moon. It is on these days that the main rules binding on all monastics, the Monastic Code or the Pātimokkha, is recited. The chapter also gives the rules regarding the boundary, the sīmā, that defines the extent of a single monastic community. Rules on making amends for offenses are also found here.", 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd3', 'root_name': 'Vassūpanāyikakkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Rains Season ', 'acronym': 'Kd 3', 'blurb': 'The Vassūpanāyikakkhandhaka, “the Chapter on entering the rainy-season residence”, prohibits monastics from traveling during three months of the rainy season. Instead they should enter the rainy-season residence in a suitable place. It then gives a number of exemptions because of which a monastic may travel for a maximum of seven days to look after urgent business.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd4', 'root_name': 'Pavāraṇākkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Invitation ', 'acronym': 'Kd 4', 'blurb': 'The Pavāraṇākhandhaka, “the Chapter on the invitation ceremony”, concerns the rules that apply to the ceremony of inviting correction from one’s fellow monastics. This ceremony is held annually at the very end of the rain-season residence, and is compulsory for all monastics.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd5', 'root_name': 'Cammakkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Leather ', 'acronym': 'Kd 5', 'blurb': 'The Cammakkhandhaka, “the Chapter on skins”, contains rules on the use of footwear and skins, as well as vehicles and beds. The chapter includes the inspiring stories of the monk Soṇa Koḷivisa who was the Buddha’s foremost disciple in putting forth energy and the monk Soṇa Kuṭikaṇṇa who became a monk in the distant country of Avantī where Buddhism had barely arrived. It also mentions a number of rules that are relaxed for lands outside of the middle Ganges plain.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd6', 'root_name': 'Bhesajjakkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Medicine ', 'acronym': 'Kd 6', 'blurb': 'The Bhesajjakkhandhaka, “the Chapter on medicines”, concerns allowable medicines and medical treatment. The rules laid down here include prohibitions against various kinds of meat and against cooking by monastics. The chapter contains the remarkable story of the monk Pilindavaccha and his supernormal powers. It also features the stories of the courtesan Ambapālī offering her mango grove to the Sangha, the conversion of general Sīha, and the exceptional layman Meṇḍaka, after whom the Meṇḍaka allowance is named. This allowance enables lay supporters to deposit a fund with a steward, who is to be approached by a designated monastic in need of requisites. The chapter concludes with four general standards to help monastics decide what is and what is not allowable.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd7', 'root_name': 'Kathinakkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Robe-Making Season ', 'acronym': 'Kd 7', 'blurb': 'The Kathinakkhandhaka, “the Chapter on the robe-making ceremony”, describes the procedure and rules for the robe-making ceremony that is normally held in the last month of the rainy season, after the rainy-season residence has been completed. Once this ceremony has been performed, the robe-making season lasts until the end of the cold season, unless certain conditions are fulfilled. Most of this chapter consists of a detailed analysis of those conditions.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd8', 'root_name': 'Cīvarakkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Robes ', 'acronym': 'Kd 8', 'blurb': 'The Cīvarakkhandhaka, “the Chapter on robe-cloth”, gives a number of rules on robes, robe-cloth, and dyeing equipment, as well as rules on inheritance. Here we find the long story of the doctor Jīvaka, the Buddha’s personal physician, and the story of Visākha, the Buddha’s main female lay supporter, who shows her understanding of the connection between generosity and success in meditation. This chapter also contains the inspiring story of the Buddha and Ānanda washing a monk who has dysentery.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd9', 'root_name': 'Campeyyakkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'At Campā ', 'acronym': 'Kd 9', 'blurb': "The Campeyyakkhandhaka, “the Chapter on those from Campā”, contains a technical discussion on the validity of formal monastic procedures, saṅghakamma. The chapter starts with the story of the monk Kassapagotta who is maliciously accused of having committed an offense.", 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd10', 'root_name': 'Kosambakakkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'At Kosambi ', 'acronym': 'Kd 10', 'blurb': 'The Kosambakakkhandhaka, “the Chapter on those from Kosambī”, discusses how to deal with a split in the Sangha. The chapter begins with the story of “the Kosambī incident”, which led to a serious dispute and spilt in the Sangha. The Buddha tells the story of Dīghāvu, a longer version of the Kosambiya Jātaka of the Jātaka collection, in an attempt at getting the monks to come to their senses. Failing at this, he goes to visit the three friends Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila, who exemplify the art of living in harmony.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd11', 'root_name': 'Kammakkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Saṅgha Procedures ', 'acronym': 'Kd 11', 'blurb': 'The Kammakkhandhaka, “the Chapter on procedures”, describes in technical detail the validity of formal procedures that involve sanctions against an offender. The chapter discusses the enactment of such procedures, the mode of conduct required of the offender to deserve release, and the lifting of the procedure.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd12', 'root_name': 'Pārivāsikakkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Probation ', 'acronym': 'Kd 12', 'blurb': "The Pārivāsikakkhandhaka, “the Chapter on those on probation”, contains a detailed description of the conduct required of a monastic who has committed an offense entailing suspension, a saṅghādisesa, so as to deserve rehabilitation.", 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd13', 'root_name': 'Samuccayakkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Collected Procedures ', 'acronym': 'Kd 13', 'blurb': "The Samuccayakkhandhaka, “the Chapter on accumulation”, describes in detail the process of making amends for a monastic who has committed an offense entailing suspension, a saṅghādisesa.", 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd14', 'root_name': 'Samathakkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Settlement ', 'acronym': 'Kd 14', 'blurb': "The Samathakkhandhaka, “the Chapter on the settling of legal issues”, gives a detailed description of how the principles for the resolution of legal issues (the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma), the last seven “rules” of the Monastic Code, are to be applied in practice. The chapter includes a technical discussion on the nature of the four kinds of legal issues.", 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd15', 'root_name': 'Khuddakavatthukkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Minor Matters ', 'acronym': 'Kd 15', 'blurb': 'The Khuddakavatthukkhandhaka, “the Chapter with short topics”, contains a large and diverse number of minor rules, including rules on allowable buildings. A recurrent theme is that luxurious items and sensual indulgence are not allowed. The verses to protect against dangerous insects and snakes, the so-called Khandhaparitta, are found here. The procedure of “overturning the bowl” is described, a procedure used against lay people who act against the interest of Buddhism. This chapter also includes the much-debated instruction for monastics to learn the Teachings using the Buddha’s own way of expression.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd16', 'root_name': 'Senāsanakkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Lodgings ', 'acronym': 'Kd 16', 'blurb': 'The Senāsanakkhandhaka, “the Chapter on dwellings”, gives further rules on allowable buildings, including allowable methods for constructing and finishing them, as well as allowable furnishings. A number of minor rules are laid down, as are the procedures for appointing community officials. The chapter tells the story of Anāthapiṇḍika, perhaps the greatest benefactor of Buddhism in the very earliest period. Here we also find the Tittira Jātaka tale, “the Partridge Jātaka”, found in a slightly different form in the Jātaka collection.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd17', 'root_name': 'Saṁghabhedakakkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Schism in the Saṅgha ', 'acronym': 'Kd 17', 'blurb': "The Saṅghabhedakakkhandhaka, “the Chapter on schism”, begins by telling the story of the going forth of a number of the Buddha’s relatives, including Anuruddha and Devadatta. The story continues with Devadatta’s ambition to lead the Sangha—including the story of King Ajātasattu murdering his father and Devadatta’s attempts to kill the Buddha—his actions eventually resulting in schism. As part of this the Buddha lays down an “announcement procedure”, pakāsanīyakamma, by which the Sangha can distance itself from the actions of any particular individual. The chapter concludes with a technical discussion on schism.", 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd18', 'root_name': 'Vattakkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Duties ', 'acronym': 'Kd 18', 'blurb': 'The Vattakkhandhaka, “the Chapter on conduct”, lays down the rules of conduct that apply in a variety of circumstances, such as those between teacher and student; those for visiting, resident, and departing monastics; those for alms-round and forest dwelling; those for dining halls, dwellings, restrooms, and saunas.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd19', 'root_name': 'Pātimokkhaṭṭhapanakkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Setting Aside the Sabbath ', 'acronym': 'Kd 19', 'blurb': 'The Pātimokkhaṭṭhapanakkhandhaka, “the Chapter on the cancellation of the Monastic Code”, allows a monastic to exclude another from the Pātimokkha recitation if they have not confessed their offenses beforehand. This chapter also describes the qualities that should be present in oneself before correcting another.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd20', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhunikkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Nuns ', 'acronym': 'Kd 20', 'blurb': 'The Bhikkhunikkhandhaka, “the Chapter on nuns”, comprises all the rules outside of the Monastic Code, the Pātimokkha, that are specific to the nuns, including the ordination ceremony and ordination by messenger. The chapter begins with the ordination of Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī, which marks the beginning of the Sangha of nuns.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd21', 'root_name': 'Pañcasatikakkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Council of the Five Hundred ', 'acronym': 'Kd 21', 'blurb': "The Pañcasatikakkhandhaka, “the Chapter on the assembly of five hundred”, tells the story of the first communal recitation (saṅgīti) of the discourses of the Buddha at Rājagaha, otherwise known as “the first council”. Ānanda, the Buddha’s personal attendant, recited the discourses, while Upāli recited the Monastic Law.", 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-kd22', 'root_name': 'Sattasatikakkhandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Council of the Seven Hundred ', 'acronym': 'Kd 22', 'blurb': 'The Sattasatikakkhandhaka, “the Chapter on the assembly of seven hundred”, tells the story of a major disagreement in the Sangha about aspects of the Monastic Law, most importantly about the use of money. After a long process, it is agreed that monastics may not use money. This episode is often referred to as “the second council”.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}]

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pācittiya, “entailing confession”. There are one hundred and sixty-six such rules for the nuns, seventy of which are shared with the monks. This is the largest class of rules in the Monastic Code. These rules, together with all the other rules apart from those entailing expulsion and suspension, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is no penalty apart from confession.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the monks’ rules”) contains the monastic code for monks, the Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Vibhaṅga is divided into eight chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 218 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”) and the dhamma-anudhamma (“the rules and their applications”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the nuns’ rules”) contains the monastic code for nuns, the Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga is divided into six chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the monks’ rules”) contains the monastic code for monks, the Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Vibhaṅga is divided into nine chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”) and the dhamma-anudhamma (“the rules and their applications”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.

blurb: There are seven adhikaraṇasamathadhamma, “principles for the settling of legal issues”, which are the same for the nuns and the monks. These are not rules in the ordinary sense and as such fall outside of the classification into serious and light offenses. Instead, they set out the proper methods for dealing with legal issues. The detailed explanation for these is found in the Samathakkhandhaka. The legal issues to be settled through these principles fall into four categories: disputes, accusations, offenses, and proceedings. “Proceedings” includes monastic procedures such as ordination and the keeping of the observance day (uposatha).

blurb: The Abhisamācārika (“the supplementary regulations”) is a text only found in the Mahāsaṅghika school and its sub-schools. The text has been transmitted in a Chinese translation, and in a Sanskrit version that belongs to the Lokuttaravāda school.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-vibhaṅga or Mahā-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the monks’ rules” or “the great analysis”), or simply the Vibhaṅga for short, contains the Monastic Code for monks, the Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Vibhaṅga is divided into eight chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”) and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter. These units begin with one or more origin stories, which tell the circumstances that led the Buddha to lay down a particular rule. The rule is then stated, followed by a word commentary that analyzes every significant word contained in the rule. After the word commentary follows a permutation series in which a variety of different scenarios are evaluated and offenses assigned as appropriate. At the end comes a non-offense clause, stating important exceptions to the rule, sometimes followed by individual case studies, in which the Buddha decides the offense incurred in ambiguous cases.
children: [{'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb-pj', 'root_name': 'Pārājika', 'translated_name': 'Expulsion ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as pārājika. The exact meaning of the Pali word is disputed, but there is no doubt that it refers to expulsion from the Sangha. There are four such rules for the monks, all of which are shared with the nuns. Anyone who breaches any of these rules immediately loses his status as a monk. He is expelled from the Sangha and ineligible for re-ordination for the rest of his life. The pārājikas, together with the next category of rules, the saṅghādisesas, are collectively known as serious offenses, garukāpatti. These rules are the most fundamental ones for the proper living of the monastic life.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 8}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb-ss', 'root_name': 'Saṅghādisesa', 'translated_name': 'Suspension ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as saṅghādisesa. The meaning of the word is disputed, but according to the commentary it means that the Sangha is required at the beginning (ādi) and for the rest (sesa) of the procedure. There are thirteen such rules for the monks, seven of which are shared with the nuns. Offenders must undergo a period of probation before being rehabilitated to their former status in the Sangha.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 26}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb-ay', 'root_name': 'Aniyata', 'translated_name': 'Undetermined ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as aniyata, “undetermined”. There are two such rules for the monks, but none for the nuns. These are procedures to establish a course of action when a monk is accused of behaving in a sexually inappropriate way with a woman.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb-np', 'root_name': 'Nissaggiya Pācittiya', 'translated_name': 'Relinquishment With Confession ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as nissaggiya pācittiya, “entailing relinquishment and confession”. There are thirty such rules for the monks, the same number as for the nuns, although only eighteen are held in common. These rules, together with the remaining rules of the Monastic Code, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is usually no penalty apart from confession. For the nissaggiya pācittiyas, however, any item involved in the committing of an offense must be relinquished. Once the offense has been confessed, the item is, with a few exceptions, returned to the offender.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 57}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb-pc', 'root_name': 'Pācittiya', 'translated_name': 'Confession ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as pācittiya, “entailing confession”. There are ninety-two such rules for the monks, seventy of which are shared with the nuns. This is the largest class of rules in the Monastic Code. These rules, together with all the other rules apart from those entailing expulsion and suspension, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is no penalty apart from confession.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 201}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb-pd', 'root_name': 'Pāṭidesanīya', 'translated_name': 'Acknowledgment ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as pāṭidesanīya, “entailing acknowledgement”. There are four such rules for the monks, none of which are shared with the nuns. What distinguishes these rules from the pācittiyas is the manner of confession. For these rules the confession is done using a unique formula, with the second rule being the only one in the Monastic Code where all the offenders confess together as a group.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 11}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb-sk', 'root_name': 'Sekhiya', 'translated_name': 'Rules for Training ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as sekhiya, “involving training”. There are seventy-five such rules, and they are the same both for the monks and the nuns. The sekhiyas are mostly rules of etiquette. Breaking a sekhiya is only considered to be a transgression if the offender is acting out of disrespect for the rule.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 97}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb-as', 'root_name': 'Adhikaraṇasamatha', 'translated_name': 'Settling Legal Issues ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "There are seven adhikaraṇasamathadhamma, “principles for the settling of legal issues”, which are the same for the nuns and the monks. These are not rules in the ordinary sense and as such fall outside of the classification into serious and light offenses. Instead, they set out the proper methods for dealing with legal issues. The detailed explanation for these is found in the Samathakkhandhaka. The legal issues to be settled through these principles fall into four categories: disputes, accusations, offenses, and proceedings. “Proceedings” includes monastic procedures such as ordination and the keeping of the observance day (uposatha).", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}]

blurb: The Upāliparipucchā (“the questions of Upāli”) is found in the Sarvāstivāda school and as two independent texts not affiliated with a school. In other schools, an Upāliparipucchā is included in other works, such as the Mūlasarvāstivāsa Uttaragantha and the Theravāda Parivāra. This version, 優波離問佛經 at Taishō Vol. 24, No. 1466, was translated by Guṇaśāla in the Song Dynasty in one scroll.

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pāṭidesanīya, “entailing acknowledgement”. There are four such rules for the monks, none of which are shared with the nuns. What distinguishes these rules from the pācittiyas is the manner of confession. For these rules the confession is done using a unique formula, with the second rule being the only one in the Monastic Code where all the offenders confess together as a group.

translated_name: Monastic Law of the Dharmaguptaka School
blurb: The Monastic Law for the Dharmaguptaka school in Chinese. This school originally flourished in North-western India and had a large influence on Central Asia and China. Monastics in East Asia follow this Vinaya. Most of the Vinaya texts we have today were translated from 410–412 CE by the Kashmiri monk Buddhayaśas, who recited the entire text from memory, together with Zhu Fonian.
children: [{'uid': 'lzh-dg-bu-vb', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Vibhaṅga', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules and Their Analysis ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Dg Bu Vb', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the monks’ rules”) contains the monastic code for monks, the Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Vibhaṅga is divided into eight chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-dg-bi-vb', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhunī Vibhaṅga', 'translated_name': 'Nuns’ Rules and Their Analysis ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Dg Bi Vb', 'blurb': 'The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the nuns’ rules”) contains the monastic code for nuns, the Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as saṅghādisesa. The meaning of the word is disputed, but according to the commentary it means that the Sangha is required at the beginning (ādi) and for the rest (sesa) of the procedure. There are thirteen such rules for the monks, seven of which are shared with the nuns. Offenders must undergo a period of probation before being rehabilitated to their former status in the Sangha.
children: [{'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-ss1', 'root_name': 'Sukkavisaṭṭhi', 'translated_name': 'Masturbation ', 'acronym': 'Bu Ss 1', 'blurb': 'A monk who intentionally ejaculates is to be suspended. The introductory narrative to this and the next four rules, as well as a number of other rules in the monastic code, feature the monk Udāyī, who had a serious problem with keeping his sexual urges in check. Either that or he is a literary stand-in for the real offenders.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-ss2', 'root_name': 'Kāyasaṁsagga', 'translated_name': 'Physical Contact ', 'acronym': 'Bu Ss 2', 'blurb': 'A lustful monk who touches a woman is to be suspended.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-ss3', 'root_name': 'Duṭṭhullavācā', 'translated_name': 'Indecent Speech ', 'acronym': 'Bu Ss 3', 'blurb': 'A lustful monk who uses sexually explicit language when speaking to a woman is to be suspended.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-ss4', 'root_name': 'Attakāmpāricariya', 'translated_name': 'Encouraging Someone to Serve One’s Desires ', 'acronym': 'Bu Ss 4', 'blurb': 'A lustful monk who recommends to a woman that they have sexual intercourse is to be suspended.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-ss5', 'root_name': 'Sañcaritta', 'translated_name': 'Matchmaking ', 'acronym': 'Bu Ss 5', 'blurb': 'A monk who acts as a go-between for a relationship between a man and a woman is to be suspended.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-ss6', 'root_name': 'Kuṭikāra', 'translated_name': 'Building a Hut ', 'acronym': 'Bu Ss 6', 'blurb': "When a monk builds a hut by means of begging, he must get the Order to approve the site and the hut must not exceed the maximum size limit. A monk who breaches either of these conditions is to be suspended. The origin story to this rule includes the Maṇikaṇṭha Jātaka tale, found in a slightly different form in the Jātaka collection. There is also another edifying tale and an apparent reference to Raṭṭhapāla of the Raṭṭhapāla Sutta, MN82.", 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-ss7', 'root_name': 'Vihārakāra', 'translated_name': 'Building a Dwelling ', 'acronym': 'Bu Ss 7', 'blurb': 'A monk who builds a large dwelling without getting the site approved by the Order is to be suspended.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-ss8', 'root_name': 'Duṭṭhadosa', 'translated_name': 'Making a Groundless Accusation Out of Anger ', 'acronym': 'Bu Ss 8', 'blurb': "A monk who in anger falsely accuses another monk of an offense entailing expulsion is to be suspended. blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 263 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 263 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the monks’ rules”) contains the monastic code for monks, the Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Vibhaṅga is divided into eight chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pārājika. The exact meaning of the Pali word is disputed, but there is no doubt that it refers to expulsion from the Sangha. There are four such rules for the monks, all of which are shared with the nuns. Anyone who breaches any of these rules immediately loses his status as a monk. He is expelled from the Sangha and ineligible for re-ordination for the rest of his life. The pārājikas, together with the next category of rules, the saṅghādisesas, are collectively known as serious offenses, garukāpatti. These rules are the most fundamental ones for the proper living of the monastic life.
children: [{'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-pj1', 'root_name': 'Methunadhamma', 'translated_name': 'Sexual Intercourse ', 'acronym': 'Bu Pj 1', 'blurb': 'A monk who has sexual intercourse is expelled. The introduction to the rule tells the background story to the laying down of the monastic law. The main principle applied by the Buddha was to lay down rules and procedures only when required by circumstances.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-pj2', 'root_name': 'Adinnādāna', 'translated_name': 'Theft ', 'acronym': 'Bu Pj 2', 'blurb': 'A monk who steals anything of value is expelled.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-pj3', 'root_name': 'Manussaviggaha', 'translated_name': 'Murder ', 'acronym': 'Bu Pj 3', 'blurb': 'A monk who kills a human being is expelled. The origin narrative to this rule includes an unusual and much debated story about a number of monks who meditate on the unattractiveness of the body. As a result they end up committing suicide and asking others to kill them. The Buddha then teaches the meditation on mindfulness of breathing.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-pj4', 'root_name': 'Uttarimanussadhamma', 'translated_name': 'Laying False Claim to Superhuman Attainments ', 'acronym': 'Bu Pj 4', 'blurb': 'A monk who falsely claims a profound spiritual attainment is expelled. In the origin story to this rule the Buddha declares that anyone who gets people to support him or her by lying about their spiritual attainments is the worst kind of thief.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}]

blurb: The Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for nuns,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 355 such rules for the nuns, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

translated_name: Monastic Law of the Mūlasarvāstivāda School
blurb: The Monastic Law for the Mūlasarvāstivāda school in Sanskrit. The debate about the origins of this school is still ongoing but it is clear that it had a large influence on Central Asia. Monastics of the Tibetan tradition follow this Vinaya. The Sanskrit version of this Vinaya is only partially preserved. Full texts survive in Chinese and Tibetan translation.
children: [{'uid': 'san-mu-kd', 'root_name': 'Khandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Chapters on Legal Topics ', 'acronym': 'San Mu Kd', 'blurb': 'The Khandhakas (“the Chapters”) comprise the rules and regulations of both Sanghas that fall outside of the monastic code, the pātimokkha. There are about 20 individual Khandhakas, most of which discuss a more or less unified topic. The Khandhakas include a variety of material, such as assorted biographical material of a number of eminent disciples and some notorious ones. They also incorporate a few Jātakas and other tales. The whole collection is structured around the life of the Buddha after his awakening.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'san', 'root_lang_name': 'Sanskrit', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'san-mu-bu-pm-gbm3', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Pātimokkha (Gilgit 3)', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules (Gilgit 3 edition) ', 'acronym': 'San Mu Bu Pm GBM 3', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 258 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'san', 'root_lang_name': 'Sanskrit', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'san-mu-bu-pm-gbm2', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Pātimokkha (Gilgit 2)', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules (Gilgit 2 edition) ', 'acronym': 'San Mu Bu Pm GBM 2', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are about 250 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'san', 'root_lang_name': 'Sanskrit', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'san-mu-bu-kam', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Kammavācā', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Legal Proceedings ', 'acronym': 'San Mu Bu Kam', 'blurb': 'The Bhikkhu-kammavācā (“the monks’ legal proceedings”) are compilations of the formulas that are recited by monks to carry out the legal proceedings of the Sangha. They were excerpted from the Vibhaṅga.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'san', 'root_lang_name': 'Sanskrit', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'san-mu-mpt-bu-pm', 'root_name': 'Mahāvyutpatti', 'translated_name': 'Great Dictionary ', 'acronym': 'Mpt', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 255 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'san', 'root_lang_name': 'Sanskrit', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}]

blurb: The Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for nuns,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 355 such rules for the nuns, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are at least 260 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The texts on Monastic Law (vinaya) detail the lifestyle, rules, and procedures for Buddhist monks and nuns. They provide the guidelines for Buddhist monastics to this day, and in addition, paint a detailed and vivid picture of everyday life in ancient India.
children: [{'uid': 'pli-tv-vi', 'root_name': 'Theravāda Vinayapiṭaka', 'translated_name': 'Monastic Law of the Theravāda School ', 'acronym': 'Tv Vi', 'blurb': 'The Monastic Law for the Theravāda school in Pali. This collection is followed by mendicants of the Theravāda school. It is the only Vinaya for which we have a complete collection in the original Indic.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 931}, {'uid': 'lzh-mg-vi', 'root_name': 'Mahāsaṅghika Vinaya', 'translated_name': 'Monastic Law of the Mahāsaṅghika School ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mg Vi', 'blurb': 'The Monastic Law for the Mahāsaṁghika school in Chinese. This school originally flourished in the area of Magadha in India and is now extinct. It was created during the first schism, and therefore its Vinaya has some unique features not found in other schools. Most of the Vinaya texts we have today were brought from Pāṭaliputra in India to China by the Chinese monk Faxian. He then translated them into Chinese together with the Indian monk Buddhabhadra from 416–418 CE.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'san-mg-vi', 'root_name': 'Mahāsaṅghika Vinaya', 'translated_name': 'Monastic Law of the Mahāsaṅghika School ', 'acronym': 'San Mg Vi', 'blurb': 'The Monastic Law for the Mahāsaṁghika school in Sanskrit. This school originally flourished in the area of Magadha in India and is now extinct. It was created during the first schism, and therefore its Vinaya has some unique features not found in other schools. Only the Bhikkhu-pātimokkha has been preserved in Sanskrit.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'san', 'root_lang_name': 'Sanskrit', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'san-lo-vi', 'root_name': 'Lokuttaravāda Vinaya', 'translated_name': 'Monastic Law of the Lokuttaravāda School ', 'acronym': 'San Lo Vi', 'blurb': 'The Monastic Law for the Lokuttaravāda school in Sanskrit. This is a sub-school of the Mahāsaṁghika and is now extinct. It is not known where the adherents of this school lived, but in the early 7th century, a community existed in Bāmīyan. The text is incomplete, and most of what we have today was discovered in Tibet as palm-leaf manuscripts by Tripiṭakācārya Śri Rāhula Sānkṛtyāyana between 1935–1938. It is of special importance for bhikkhunī Vinaya studies, since it has the only complete Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga in an Indian language besides the Pāli.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'san', 'root_lang_name': 'Sanskrit', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mi-vi', 'root_name': 'Mahīśāsaka Vinaya', 'translated_name': 'Monastic Law of the Mahīśāsaka School ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mi Vi', 'blurb': 'The Monastic Law for the Mahīśāsaka school in Chinese. This school originated in the area of Avanti in India but then spread throughout India and to Sri Lanka. It is now extinct. Most of the Vinaya texts we have today were brought from the Abhayagiri Vihāra in Sri Lanka to China by the Chinese monk Faxian. They were translated from Sanskrit into Chinese by the Kashmiri monk Buddhajīva together with Zhu Daosheng in 434 CE.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-dg-vi', 'root_name': 'Dharmaguptaka Vinaya', 'translated_name': 'Monastic Law of the Dharmaguptaka School ', 'acronym': 'Dg Vi', 'blurb': 'The Monastic Law for the Dharmaguptaka school in Chinese. This school originally flourished in North-western India and had a large influence on Central Asia and China. Monastics in East Asia follow this Vinaya. Most of the Vinaya texts we have today were translated from 410–412 CE by the Kashmiri monk Buddhayaśas, who recited the entire text from memory, together with Zhu Fonian.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'pgd-dg-vi', 'root_name': 'Dharmaguptaka Vinaya', 'translated_name': 'Monastic Law of the Dharmaguptaka School ', 'acronym': 'Dg Vi', 'blurb': 'The Monastic Law for the Dharmaguptaka school in Gandhari. This school originally flourished in North-western India and had a large influence on Central Asia and China. Monastics in East Asia follow this Vinaya.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pgd', 'root_lang_name': 'Gāndhārī', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-sarv-vi', 'root_name': 'Sarvāstivāda Vinaya', 'translated_name': 'Monastic Law of the Sarvāstivāda School ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Sarv Vi', 'blurb': 'The Monastic Law for the Sarvāstivāda school in Chinese. This school spread throughout North India and Central Asia. The Sarvāstivāda Vinaya was the most common Vinaya in China before they changed to the Dharmaguptaka. The Sarvāstivāda school is now extinct. Most of the Vinaya texts we have today were translated from about 404–409 CE by the Kashmiri monks Kumārajīva and Puṇyatāra. When Puṇyatāra died, Dharmaruci replaced him and finished the translation.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'san-sarv-vi', 'root_name': 'Sarvāstivāda Vinaya', 'translated_name': 'Monastic Law of the Sarvāstivāda School ', 'acronym': 'San Sarv Vi', 'blurb': 'The Monastic Law for the Sarvāstivāda school in Sanskrit. This school spread throughout North India and Central Asia. The Sarvāstivāda Vinaya was the most common Vinaya in China before they changed to the Dharmaguptaka. The Sarvāstivāda school is now extinct.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'san', 'root_lang_name': 'Sanskrit', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mu-vi', 'root_name': 'Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya', 'translated_name': 'Monastic Law of the Mūlasarvāstivāda School ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mu Vi', 'blurb': 'The Monastic Law for the Mūlasarvāstivāda school in Chinese. The debate about the origins of this school is still ongoing but it is clear that it had a large influence on Central Asia. Monastics of the Tibetan tradition follow this Vinaya. Most of the Vinaya texts in Chinese we have today were translated between 695 and 713 CE by Yijing. We also have a full Vinaya translation in Tibetan, and a part of the original Sanskrit.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'san-mu-vi', 'root_name': 'Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya', 'translated_name': 'Monastic Law of the Mūlasarvāstivāda School ', 'acronym': 'San Mu Vi', 'blurb': 'The Monastic Law for the Mūlasarvāstivāda school in Sanskrit. The debate about the origins of this school is still ongoing but it is clear that it had a large influence on Central Asia. Monastics of the Tibetan tradition follow this Vinaya. The Sanskrit version of this Vinaya is only partially preserved. Full texts survive in Chinese and Tibetan translation.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'san', 'root_lang_name': 'Sanskrit', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'xct-mu-vi', 'root_name': 'Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya', 'translated_name': 'Monastic Law of the Mūlasarvāstivāda School ', 'acronym': 'Xct Mu Vi', 'blurb': 'The Monastic Law for the Mūlasarvāstivāda school in Tibetan. blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as sekhiya, “involving training”. There are seventy-five such rules, and they are the same both for the monks and the nuns. The sekhiyas are mostly rules of etiquette. Breaking a sekhiya is only considered to be a transgression if the offender is acting out of disrespect for the rule.

translated_name: Monastic Law of the Sarvāstivāda School
blurb: The Monastic Law for the Sarvāstivāda school in Sanskrit. This school spread throughout North India and Central Asia. The Sarvāstivāda Vinaya was the most common Vinaya in China before they changed to the Dharmaguptaka. The Sarvāstivāda school is now extinct.
children: [{'uid': 'san-sarv-bu-pm-tf11', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Pātimokkha (Turfan 11)', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules (Turfan 11 edition) ', 'acronym': 'San Sarv Bu Pm Tf 11', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 263 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'san', 'root_lang_name': 'Sanskrit', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'san-sarv-bu-pm-finot', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Pātimokkha (Finot)', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules (Finot edition) ', 'acronym': 'San Sarv Bu Pm Finot', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as saṅghādisesa. The meaning of the word is disputed, but according to the commentary it means that the Sangha is required at the beginning (ādi) and for the rest (sesa) of the procedure. There are seventeen such rules for the nuns, seven of which are shared with the monks. Offenders must undergo a period of probation before being rehabilitated to their former status in the Sangha.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-pakiṇṇaka (“the assorted rules for monks”) is a collection of miscellaneous rules and regulations for monks outside the Pātimokkha. Many of the rules also apply to nuns. This collection only exists in the Mahāsaṁghika school and its sub-schools.

blurb: The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the nuns’ rules”) contains the Monastic Code for nuns, the Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga is divided into seven chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter. These units begin with one or more origin stories, which tell the circumstances that led the Buddha to lay down a particular rule. The rule is then stated, followed by a word commentary that analyzes every significant word contained in the rule. After the word commentary follows a permutation series in which a variety of different scenarios are evaluated and offenses assigned as appropriate. At the end comes a non-offense clause, stating important exceptions to the rule, sometimes followed by individual case studies, in which the Buddha decides the offense incurred in ambiguous cases.
children: [{'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-vb-pj', 'root_name': 'Pārājika', 'translated_name': 'Expulsion', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as pārājika. The exact meaning of the Pali word is disputed, but there is no doubt that it refers to expulsion from the monastic Sangha. There are eight such rules for the nuns, four of which are shared with the monks. Anyone who breaches any of these rules immediately loses her status as a nun. She is expelled from the Sangha and ineligible for re-ordination for the rest of her life. The pārājikas, together with the next category of rules, the saṅghādisesas, are collectively known as serious offenses, garukāpatti. These rules are the most fundamental ones for the proper living of the monastic life.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 13}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-vb-ss', 'root_name': 'Saṅghādisesa', 'translated_name': 'Suspension', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as saṅghādisesa. The meaning of the word is disputed, but according to the commentary it means that the Sangha is required at the beginning (ādi) and for the rest (sesa) of the procedure. There are seventeen such rules for the nuns, seven of which are shared with the monks. Offenders must undergo a period of probation before being rehabilitated to their former status in the Sangha.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 30}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-vb-np', 'root_name': 'NissaggiyaPācittiya', 'translated_name': 'Relinquishment With Confession', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as nissaggiya pācittiya, “entailing relinquishment and confession”. There are thirty such rules for the nuns, the same number as for the monks, although only eighteen are held in common. These rules, together with the remaining rules of the Monastic Code, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is usually no penalty apart from confession. For the nissaggiya pācittiyas, however, any item involved in the committing of an offense must be relinquished. Once the offense has been confessed, the item is, with a few exceptions, returned to the offender.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 34}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-vb-pc', 'root_name': 'Pācittiya', 'translated_name': 'Confession', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as pācittiya, “entailing confession”. There are one hundred and sixty-six such rules for the nuns, seventy of which are shared with the monks. This is the largest class of rules in the Monastic Code. These rules, together with all the other rules apart from those entailing expulsion and suspension, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is no penalty apart from confession.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 248}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-vb-pd', 'root_name': 'Pāṭidesanīya', 'translated_name': 'Acknowledgment', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as pāṭidesanīya, “entailing acknowledgement”. There are eight such rules for the nuns. These eight rules for the nuns are equivalent to a single rule for the monks (bhikkhu-pācittiya 39). In summary, they say that a nun who asks for special food must acknowledge the offense.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-vb-sk', 'root_name': 'Sekhiya', 'translated_name': 'Rules for Training', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The rules in this category are known in Pali as sekhiya, “involving training”. There are seventy-five such rules, and they are the same both for the monks and the nuns. The sekhiyas are mostly rules of etiquette. Breaking a sekhiya is only considered to be a transgression if the offender is acting out of disrespect for the rule.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-vb-as', 'root_name': 'Adhikaraṇasamatha', 'translated_name': 'Settling Legal Issues', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "There are seven adhikaraṇasamathadhamma, “principles for the settling of legal issues”, which are the same for the nuns and the monks. These are not rules in the ordinary sense and as such fall outside of the classification into serious and light offenses. Instead, they set out the proper methods for dealing with legal issues. The detailed explanation for these is found in the Samathakkhandhaka. The legal issues to be settled through these principles fall into four categories: disputes, accusations, offenses, and proceedings. “Proceedings” includes monastic procedures such as ordination and the keeping of the observance day (uposatha).", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}]

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as nissaggiya pācittiya, “entailing relinquishment and confession”. There are thirty such rules for the nuns, the same number as for the monks, although only eighteen are held in common. These rules, together with the remaining rules of the Monastic Code, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is usually no penalty apart from confession. For the nissaggiya pācittiyas, however, any item involved in the committing of an offense must be relinquished. Once the offense has been confessed, the item is, with a few exceptions, returned to the offender.

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as aniyata, “undetermined”. There are two such rules for the monks, but none for the nuns. These are procedures to establish a course of action when a monk is accused of behaving in a sexually inappropriate way with a woman.
children: [{'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-ay1', 'root_name': 'Paṭhamaaniyata', 'translated_name': 'First Undetermined Offence ', 'acronym': 'Bu Ay 1', 'blurb': 'A female lay disciple may see a monk sitting in a secluded place with a woman. If she accuses him of an offense entailing expulsion, suspension, or confession, and he admits to the offense, then he incurs an offense accordingly.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-pm-ay2', 'root_name': 'Dutiyaaniyata', 'translated_name': 'Second Undetermined Offence ', 'acronym': 'Bu Ay 2', 'blurb': 'A female lay disciple may see a monk sitting in private with a woman. If she accuses him of an offense entailing suspension or confession, and he admits to the offense, then he incurs an offense accordingly.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}]

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as saṅghādisesa. The meaning of the word is disputed, but according to the commentary it means that the Sangha is required at the beginning (ādi) and for the rest (sesa) of the procedure. There are thirteen such rules for the monks, seven of which are shared with the nuns. Offenders must undergo a period of probation before being rehabilitated to their former status in the Sangha.

There is also another edifying tale and an apparent reference to Raṭṭhapāla of the Raṭṭhapāla Sutta, MN82.", 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb-ss7', 'root_name': 'Vihārakāra', 'translated_name': 'Building a Dwelling ', 'acronym': 'Bu Ss 7', 'blurb': 'A monk who builds a large dwelling without getting the site approved by the Order is to be suspended.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb-ss8', 'root_name': 'Duṭṭhadosa', 'translated_name': 'Making a Groundless Accusation Out of Anger ', 'acronym': 'Bu Ss 8', 'blurb': "A monk who in anger falsely accuses another monk of an offense entailing expulsion is to be suspended. ", 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb-ss9', 'root_name': 'Aññabhāgiya', 'translated_name': 'Making an Accusation Out of Anger on an Irrelevant Pretext ', 'acronym': 'Bu Ss 9', 'blurb': 'A monk who in anger uses a ploy to falsely accuse another monk of an offense entailing expulsion is to be suspended.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10', 'root_name': 'Saṅghabheda', 'translated_name': 'Causing Schism in the Saṅgha ', 'acronym': 'Bu Ss 10', 'blurb': 'A monk who tries to cause a schism in the Order is to be suspended. translated_name: Monastic Law of the Mahīśāsaka School
blurb: The Monastic Law for the Mahīśāsaka school in Chinese. This school originated in the area of Avanti in India but then spread throughout India and to Sri Lanka. It is now extinct. Most of the Vinaya texts we have today were brought from the Abhayagiri Vihāra in Sri Lanka to China by the Chinese monk Faxian. They were translated from Sanskrit into Chinese by the Kashmiri monk Buddhajīva together with Zhu Daosheng in 434 CE.
children: [{'uid': 'lzh-mi-bu-vb', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Vibhaṅga', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules and Their Analysis ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mi Bu Vb', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the monks’ rules”) contains the monastic code for monks, the Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Vibhaṅga is divided into eight chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mi-bi-vb', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhunī Vibhaṅga', 'translated_name': 'Nuns’ Rules and Their Analysis ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mi Bi Vb', 'blurb': 'The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the nuns’ rules”) contains the monastic code for nuns, the Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga is divided into six chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mi-kd', 'root_name': 'Khandhaka', 'translated_name': 'Chapters on Legal Topics ', 'acronym': 'Mi Kd', 'blurb': 'The Khandhakas (“the Chapters”) comprise the rules and regulations of both Sanghas that fall outside of the monastic code, the pātimokkha. There are about 20 individual Khandhakas, most of which discuss a more or less unified topic. The Khandhakas include a variety of material, such as assorted biographical material of a number of eminent disciples and some notorious ones. They also incorporate a few Jātakas and other tales, as well as the stories of the first communal recitation after the Buddha’s passing away and the famous Vesālī affair, sometimes known as “the second council.” The whole collection is structured around the life of the Buddha after his awakening.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mi-vs', 'root_name': 'Saṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Passages ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mi VS', 'blurb': 'The Saṁyutta (“the linked passages”) is a short text found in the Mahīśāsaka and Dharmaguptaka schools. It is a parallel of a chapter in the Theravāda Parivāra.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mi-bu-pm', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Pātimokkha', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Rules ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mi Bu Pm', 'blurb': "The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 251 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mi-bi-pm', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhunī Pātimokkha', 'translated_name': 'Nuns’ Rules ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mi Bi Pm', 'blurb': 'The Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for nuns,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 373 such rules for the nuns, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'lzh-mi-bu-kam', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhu Kammavācā', 'translated_name': 'Monks’ Legal Proceedings ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Mi Bu Kam', 'blurb': 'The Bhikkhu-kammavācā (“the monks’ legal proceedings”) are compilations of the formulas that are recited by monks to carry out the legal proceedings of the Sangha. They were excerpted from the Vibhaṅga.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}]

blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 263 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pāṭidesanīya, “entailing acknowledgement”. There are eight such rules for the nuns. These eight rules for the nuns are equivalent to a single rule for the monks (bhikkhu-pācittiya 39). In summary, they say that a nun who asks for special food must acknowledge the offense.

blurb: The Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for nuns,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 290 such rules for the nuns, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”) and the dhamma-anudhamma (“the rules and their applications”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the monks’ rules”) contains the monastic code for monks, the Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Vibhaṅga is divided into eight chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter.

blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are about 250 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

blurb: There are seven adhikaraṇasamathadhamma, “principles for the settling of legal issues”, which are the same for the nuns and the monks. These are not rules in the ordinary sense and as such fall outside of the classification into serious and light offenses. Instead, they set out the proper methods for dealing with legal issues. The detailed explanation for these is found in the Samathakkhandhaka. The legal issues to be settled through these principles fall into four categories: disputes, accusations, offenses, and proceedings. “Proceedings” includes monastic procedures such as ordination and the keeping of the observance day (uposatha).
children: [{'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-pm-as1', 'root_name': 'Sammukhāvinaya', 'translated_name': 'Resolution Face to Face ', 'acronym': 'Bi As 1', 'blurb': 'A legal issue can only be resolved if all those concerned are present during the process. In addition the procedure must comply with all aspects of monastic law.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-pm-as2', 'root_name': 'Sativinaya', 'translated_name': 'Resolution Through Recollection ', 'acronym': 'Bi As 2', 'blurb': 'If a nun is known for her clarity of memory, any accusations against her may be settled through that nun declaring her innocence based on her memory of the relevant events.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-pm-as3', 'root_name': 'Amūḷhavinaya', 'translated_name': 'Resolution Because of Past Insanity ', 'acronym': 'Bi As 3', 'blurb': 'A nun who is insane is not responsible for her own offenses. Any offenses she may have committed while insane can be cleared through a declaration of past insanity.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-pm-as4', 'root_name': 'Paṭiññātakaraṇa', 'translated_name': 'Admission ', 'acronym': 'Bi As 4', 'blurb': 'All offenses, except those entailing expulsion, should be cleared by making amends in the appropriate manner.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-pm-as5', 'root_name': 'Yebhuyyasikā', 'translated_name': 'Majority Decision ', 'acronym': 'Bi As 5', 'blurb': 'A dispute that drags on without resolution may be settled through majority vote.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-pm-as6', 'root_name': 'Tassapāpiyasikā', 'translated_name': 'Further Penalty ', 'acronym': 'Bi As 6', 'blurb': 'A nun who is intractable in regard to the offenses she has committed may be subject to an act of censure.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pli-tv-bi-pm-as7', 'root_name': 'Tiṇavatthāraka', 'translated_name': 'Covering With Grass', 'acronym': 'Bi As 7', 'blurb': 'If a dispute involves a number of offenses on both sides, and the Order considers that dealing with all the offenses in the usual manner is likely to lead to harshness or schism, then the Order may decide to do a procedure whereby all the offenses are cleared. blurb: The Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, “the monastic code for monks,” contains the core rules of monastic life in the form of a long list without any explanatory material. There are 255 such rules for the monks, grouped according to the type of offense incurred for breaking the rule, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”), and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.
